items.title: Exercise 1: Project Status Report (Doc A)
items.text:
Doc A — Status Report: Office Relocation (Week 4)

Current Phase: Execution. We are currently carrying out the physical move of the server room. By 5 PM today, we will be testing the new network connections (Future Continuous).

Milestones Achieved:
- Initiation: Feasibility study approved.
- Planning: Gantt chart finalized.

Upcoming Deadlines:
- By Friday, we will have completed the handover of the old keys (Future Perfect).
- By the end of next week, the IT department will have installed all workstations.

Risk Alert: We must monitor the project closely to avoid scope creep, as some departments are requesting extra cabling that wasn't in the original brief. Our primary KPI remains 'Zero Down-time'.

questions.question: What is the current phase of the project according to Doc A?
questions.explanation: Doc A explicitly states: 'Current Phase: Execution'.

questions.question: What tense is used to describe the task of testing network connections today at 5 PM?
questions.explanation: 'Will be testing' is the Future Continuous, describing an action in progress in the future.

items.prompt: Exercise 2: Project Lifecycle. In which phase do you 'review lessons learned'?
items.explanation: Lessons learned are reviewed during the 'Closure' phase of a project.

items.prompt: Exercise 3: Project Concepts. What is 'Scope Creep'?
options: A slow movement of the office building.
The uncontrolled expansion of project requirements without extra time or budget.
A type of measuring tool used by engineers.
Hiring new people at the end of a project.
items.explanation: Scope creep is when requirements expand beyond the original plan without corresponding resources.

items.prompt: Exercise 4: Project Vocabulary. Complete the sentence: 'We will use a ___ to visualize the schedule and track our ___.'
items.explanation: A Gantt chart is used to visualize schedules and track progress.

items.prompt: Exercise 5: Future Continuous. Form a sentence using the Future Continuous to describe what you will be doing next Monday at 10 AM (e.g., 'working on the report').
items.modelAnswer: Next Monday at 10 AM, I will be working on the project report.

items.prompt: Exercise 6: Future Perfect. Form a sentence using the Future Perfect to describe a deadline for next Friday (e.g., 'finish the data entry').
items.modelAnswer: By next Friday, I will have finished the data entry.

items.prompt: Exercise 7: Extracting Action Points. Based on Doc A, list the 2 upcoming deadlines mentioned using the Future Perfect structure.
items.modelAnswer:
1. By Friday, we will have completed the handover of the old keys.
2. By the end of next week, the IT department will have installed all workstations.

items.prompt: Exercise 8: Courtesy Modals. Which is the most professional way to ask for a status update on a deliverable?
options: Where is the report? You're late.
Could you please provide an update on the final deliverable? I’m hoping we will have received it by EOD so we can stay on schedule.
I need the report now for my meeting.
items.explanation: This option is polite, uses Future Perfect for expectations, and explains why the update is needed.

items.prompt: Exercise 9: Follow-up Email. Write a 50-word email to your manager announcing that a 'Milestone' has been reached. Use the Future Perfect to state when the next phase will be finished.
items.modelAnswer: Hi Sarah, I’m pleased to announce that we have reached the planning milestone for the relocation. By next Friday, we will have finished the resource allocation for the execution phase. I’ll be monitoring the Gantt chart closely for any scope creep. Thanks, Alex

items.prompt: Exercise 10: Operational Logic. If your primary goal is 'Zero Down-time', what is this measure called in project management?
items.explanation: A measurable value used to evaluate success is a KPI (Key Performance Indicator).

items.prompt: Exercise 11: Oral Presentation Prep. Prepare a script for a 3-minute project update. You must use the terms: 'Execution phase', 'Milestone', and 'Scope creep'. Use at least one Future Perfect sentence.
items.modelAnswer: [Audio Upload Required] Rubric: Logical structure (Past/Present/Future), Use of key terms, Tense accuracy.

items.prompt: Exercise 12: Oral Deadline Setting. Record a 60-second audio for your team setting expectations for the coming month. Use Future Continuous to describe the work and Future Perfect to state the final deadline.
items.modelAnswer: [Audio Upload Required] Checklist: Future Continuous accuracy, Future Perfect accuracy, Professional tone.

items.prompt: Exercise 13: Project Summary (Portfolio). Write a 200-word summary of a project you recently 'finished' (or a hypothetical one). Use at least two examples each of Future Perfect and Future Continuous to describe future expectations.
items.modelAnswer:
Project Summary: New Staff Training Program

We are currently in the planning phase of the training project. Throughout next month, we will be conducting needs analysis interviews with all department heads. By the end of that period, we will have identified the key training gaps across the organisation. 

During the execution phase in June, our lead trainers will be delivering workshops on UK English business protocols. We expect that by the middle of July, we will have trained over 50 employees. We are monitoring this closely to ensure there is no scope creep and that we meet our KPI of a 90% satisfaction rate. The closure phase is scheduled for August, during which we will be reviewing lessons learned.

items.prompt: Exercise 14: Project Timeline. Complete a timeline for an 'Email Migration' project. Phases: Initiation | Planning | Execution | Closure. (Assign one task to each).
items.modelAnswer: Initiation: Feasibility study. Planning: Draft Gantt chart. Execution: Move data to new server. Closure: Final user feedback survey.

items.prompt: Exercise 15: Weekly Mini-test. 1) Name the 4 project phases. 2) Define 'KPI'. 3) Invert for emphasis: 'I have never seen such scope creep.' 4) Form a sentence: 'By EOD / I / finish / the map' (Future Perfect).
items.modelAnswer: 1) Initiation, Planning, Execution, Closure. 2) Key Performance Indicator. 3) Never have I seen such scope creep. 4) By EOD, I will have finished the map.

items.title: Exercise 16: Waterfall vs. Agile in Administration
items.text: When managing administrative transitions, choosing the right **methodology** is vital. A **Waterfall** approach is often preferred for projects like office relocations, where the sequence of events is fixed: you cannot unpack boxes before the truck arrives. However, for internal software development or process improvement, many teams now use **Agile**. This involves breaking the project into small **Sprints**. By the time the project reaches the **closure** phase, the team **will have been iterating** on the solution for weeks, ensuring it perfectly meets user needs. Regardless of the method, administrators must define a clear **Project Charter** during **initiation** to prevent **scope creep** and ensure that all **deliverables** are aligned with corporate **KPIs**.

questions.question: Why is Waterfall often used for office relocations?
options: Because it is more flexible than Agile
Because the sequence of events is fixed
questions.explanation: The text explains Waterfall is preferred when the sequence of events is fixed (e.g., unpacking must follow the truck's arrival).

questions.question: What is an advantage of the Agile methodology mentioned in the text?
options: It allows for iteration to meet user needs
It only works for office relocations
questions.explanation: The text mentions teams will have been iterating on the solution to ensure it meets user needs.

items.title: Exercise 17: Highlighted Vocabulary
items.prompt: Match the project management terms with their descriptions.

pairs.definition: A short, fixed period of time for a specific set of tasks.
The repetition of a process to reach a goal.
The particular order in which things follow each other.
A document that formally authorizes a project.

items.prompt: Exercise 18: Project Phrasing. If a project is taking longer than planned, we say it is:
items.explanation: 'Falling behind' schedule means taking longer than planned.

items.prompt: Exercise 19: Future Perfect. Choose the correct form: 'By next Christmas, I ___ for this company for ten years.'
items.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous is used for durations leading up to a point in the future.

items.prompt: Exercise 20: Future Continuous. Choose the correct form: 'Don't call me at 2 PM; I ___ the status meeting.'
items.explanation: Future Continuous describes an action in progress at a specific time.

items.prompt: Exercise 21: Deadlines. 'We will have finalised the budget by Monday.' This means:
options: The budget will be finished on or before Monday.
The budget will start on Monday.
We will be working on the budget on Monday.
items.explanation: Future Perfect indicates completion before or at a specific deadline.

items.prompt: Exercise 22: Resource Allocation. When an administrator assigns a specific person to a task, they are:
items.explanation: Delegating is entrusting a task to someone else.

items.prompt: Exercise 23: Future Perfect Continuous. 'By 5 PM, the server ___ for 24 hours.'
items.explanation: This shows the duration of an ongoing future action.

items.prompt: Exercise 24: Project Closure. A 'Post-Mortem' is conducted to:
items.explanation: A post-mortem (or debrief) analyzes the project after it ends.

items.title: Exercise 25: Oral Recording Task 1 - Status Update
items.prompt: You are the project administrator. Record a 60-second status update for the weekly meeting. Mention: 1) Why the team has 'fallen behind', 2) The plan to 'catch up', and 3) When the team will have 'signed off on' the current phase.
items.modelAnswer: Good morning everyone. Unfortunately, we have slightly fallen behind due to a delay in vendor provisioning. However, we have allocated extra resources this weekend to catch up. By next Tuesday, the technical team will have signed off on the execution phase, and we will be moving into UAT on Wednesday.

items.title: Exercise 26: Listening Glossary
items.prompt: Familiarise yourself with these terms before the status meeting audio.

terms.definition: A provision for an unforeseen event.
Final approval on a stage or project.
To arrange events to occur at different times.

items.title: Exercise 29: Dictation
items.prompt: Listen and type the sentence accurately.
items.answer: By the end of the execution phase, we will have achieved all the milestones defined in the project charter.

items.title: Exercise 30: Gap-fill - Timeline Reporting
items.prompt: Listen and fill in the missing future tenses and phrasal verbs.
items.text: We've slightly **{fallen behind}** because of a vendor delay, but we'll work extra hours to **{catch up}**. By next Tuesday, we **{will have received}** the hardware, and the engineers **{will be installing}** it throughout the afternoon. I'm confident the project won't **{run over}** budget.
items.explanation: Uses phrasal verbs and future tenses for project status reporting.

items.title: Exercise 31: Agile Administrative Support (Doc C)
items.text:
Doc C — Case Study: Implementing Agile in Administrative Workflows

To combat **scope creep** and improve **resource allocation**, our department transitioned to an **Agile** methodology last quarter. Instead of long, linear project cycles, we now work in two-week **Sprints**. Each sprint begins with a planning session where we define specific **deliverables**. We have found that this approach reduces the risk of projects **running over** budget because we identify bottlenecks early. By the end of this month, we **will have been using** this system for exactly ninety days. Our project manager, who has already **signed off on** the final report, believes the **Waterfall** approach was too rigid for our fast-paced environment.

### Vocabulary Highlights
1. **Sprint**: A short, set period of intense work.
2. **Scope Creep**: When a project grows beyond its original plan.
3. **Deliverables**: The tangible products or results of a project.

questions.question: Why did the department transition to Agile?
options: To combat scope creep and improve resource allocation.
questions.explanation: Doc C states the transition was 'To combat scope creep and improve resource allocation'.

questions.question: What is a 'Sprint' according to the case study?
questions.explanation: The text defines Sprints as 'two-week' periods of work.

questions.question: What does the project manager think of the Waterfall approach?
options: It was perfect for the environment.
It was too rigid for the environment.
questions.explanation: The text mentions the manager 'believes the Waterfall approach was too rigid for our fast-paced environment'.

items.prompt: Exercise 32: Project Roles. Who is responsible for 'resource allocation'?
items.explanation: Resource allocation (assigning people, money, tools) is a management task.

items.prompt: Exercise 33: Timeline. 'At 10 AM tomorrow, I will be presenting the results.' If I start at 9:50 AM and finish at 10:30 AM, is this sentence correct?
items.explanation: Yes, because at 10 AM, the action (presenting) will be in progress.

items.prompt: Exercise 34: Future Perfect. 'I will have finished the report when you arrive.' If you arrive at 3 PM, when did I finish the report?
items.explanation: Future Perfect implies the action is already complete by the time of the other event.

items.prompt: Exercise 35: Project Charter. Which of these is NOT usually in a Project Charter?
options: A list of every single email sent
items.explanation: A charter is a high-level overview, not a detailed log of every communication.

items.prompt: Exercise 36: Sentence Transformation. Rewrite using the Future Perfect: 'I am finishing the budget on Friday.' (Deadline context)
items.modelAnswer: By Friday, I will have finished the budget.

items.prompt: Exercise 37: Future Perfect Continuous. Form a sentence: 'By next June / we / implement / the system / for a year'.
items.modelAnswer: By next June, we will have been implementing the system for a year.

items.prompt: Exercise 38: Professional Vocabulary. Define 'Contingency Plan' in your own words.
items.modelAnswer: A backup plan created to handle potential risks or problems that might occur during a project.

items.prompt: Exercise 39: Status Report Phrasing. Complete: 'We are currently in the ___ phase, but we might ___ ___ on the deadline if we don't hire more staff.'
items.modelAnswer: execution / fall behind

items.title: Exercise 40: Oral Recording Task 2 - Project Forecast
items.prompt: Record a 60-second forecast for the next project phase. Use at least one 'Future Perfect' and one 'Future Continuous' form. Mention: 1) What the team 'will be doing' this time next week, and 2) What milestones they 'will have achieved' by the end of the month.
items.modelAnswer: Looking ahead, this time next week we will be conducting the final UAT sessions with the end-users. By the end of the month, we will have achieved all primary milestones, and the Project Charter will have been archived. We are confident that we will not run over the original budget.

items.prompt: Exercise 41: Speculating on Duration. Use Future Perfect Continuous: 'By the time the project closes in October, the team (work) on it for eighteen months.'
items.modelAnswer: By the time the project closes in October, the team will have been working on it for eighteen months.

items.prompt: Exercise 42: Avoiding Overlaps. Use Future Continuous: 'Tomorrow afternoon, while the movers are here, I (supervise) the server setup.'
items.modelAnswer: Tomorrow afternoon, while the movers are here, I will be supervising the server setup.

items.prompt: Exercise 43: Vocabulary in context. Write a sentence about a project using the term 'deliverable'.
items.modelAnswer: The main deliverable for this phase is the architectural blueprint for the new office.

items.prompt: Exercise 44: Error Correction. Fix the sentence: 'By next week, I will being finished the Gantt chart.'
items.modelAnswer: By next week, I will have finished the Gantt chart.

items.title: Exercise 45: Weekly Review - Project Management
items.prompt: Synthesize this week's learning: 1) Contrast 'Waterfall' and 'Agile' in one sentence. 2) Write a sentence about a deadline using the 'Future Perfect'. 3) Define 'Scope Creep' and explain how an administrator can prevent it.
items.modelAnswer: 1) Waterfall is a linear and structured methodology, whereas Agile is iterative and flexible, using short cycles called sprints. 2) By Friday afternoon, the team will have finalized the resource allocation map. 3) Scope creep is the unauthorized growth of a project's objectives; an administrator can prevent it by maintaining a strict Project Charter and requiring formal sign-off for any changes.
